author: {'steamid': '76561198258961223', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2911, 'last_played': 1554791369}
review: Having played the rebirth series and now VII, I feel I have had enough. The game direction was less than the rebirth series and though it is roughly the same tone and mash up of characters and dire situations they find themselves in, it is still a little too silly for me and preferred the similar Fairy Fencer F over any of the Nep games to this date. The game ran well and I did not notice any bugs, nor much difference on high or low settings. The game keeps the lewd and saucy tradition but the Nepples are blurred and so what exactly am I fighting for? In terms of value, under ten dollars is fine for the game and better value is had closer to five.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051124510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1548, 'last_played': 1558787147}
review:
What a disappointment..

A massive step down from the Rebirth games, Grindy boring combat, Constant random encounters against trash low lvl mobs, Investment / Development is a waste of time, Over complicated combo system and the less said about the Neplunker dungeons the better.

This game feels like someone at IF looked at the calendar and saw it was time to release a new nep game and scraped up whatever the dev team had on their computers at the time and glued it all together.

I've heard the game gets better on a NG+ but I really can't be bothered to find out.

If you want a good all-round nep game try Rebirth 3, If you want more of the CPU Candidates try Rebirth 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035403576', 'num_games_owned': 1945, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 3655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3655, 'last_played': 1558792072}
review:
The story and new music are good, but the gameplay is the worst of the series.

Everything is made to make the player lose time and force them to grind for hours and hours.

SP no longer regen, but you *will* use skills a lot more in this game, because the mobs are tougher than ever.
They come in pack, they strike hard and your weapons are cardboard replicas.

Using items is mandatory as you won't have enough SP to heal, but you can forget about picking up items in dungeons. There is almost nothing to pick up now, and they're one-shot.
So, you have to kill monsters to get money, to buy healing stuff. New weapons and armors have a ridiculously low stat boost, so they won't help much in battle.

By the way, forget the easy way of the previous games:
When you level up -> no auto-healing.
When you leave a dungeon -> no auto-healing.

You have to return to a town to get fully healed. And I said "return", not "teleport" as you're used to before.
And there are now predetermined paths linking the places on the overworld map, with random encounters.
Either you will lose time with them, or be wiped by strong enemies.

The only way to beat the game without spending 100+ hours grinding is by using the weapons you can get in DLCs.
That'll give you a 20-30 levels worth stat boost, that will feel like you're barely at the recommended level for some fights.

Do not trust people saying this game is easy, it's a grinding nightmare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198815072340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 11114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3061, 'last_played': 1669588832}
review:
EDIT: lol ok so they removed the Million Arthur DLC that's kinda gay ngl. I changed my rating, it's a 9/10 without Millie. :((
I got this game for my birthday, on the 10th. I love the series, but sometimes I don't like the frustration that came with the Re;Birth games, wherein my progress would be wiped out through the enemies not attacking even though it was their turn; grinding was also a problem for me. So, I got the game with all DLC (honestly some of the DLC can be skipped, like the extra characters, I'd say. unless you actually want to hear the voice clips, which i could not figure out) and I ended up finishing the game in a week. [spoiler]I have to admit that I haven't actually finished any of the RB games (except RB2, normal ending cause I was lazy and couldn't figure out how to get true end) mostly due to the frustration that came with having to erase all my progress in the games because the enemies wouldn't attack, as well as grinding that I didn't have the patience for.[/spoiler]
Megadimension Neptunia eliminates both those problems (with DLC if you really want to go that way) and I can go through dungeons now without having to go through the anxiety that a monster that I'd attack wouldn't attack me back and I would lose my progress. 
The gameplay made a lot more sense than the RB games, and I enjoyed the story. As for the ending, [spoiler]honestly, it felt like it was rushed. I have only done the Revival Ending, and am currently working on the Ascension Ending. I feel like there wasn't enough time for all the emotions that the cast felt from Uzume's supposed death to sink in. As soon as they got back from Heart Dimension, Histoire's all like "Oh hey, yeah it's really [i]sad[/i] that Uzume's dead and all, but hey look I can revive her" I want to see the cast feel just a little bit more of sadness, maybe a day, while Histoire's scouring the books to see if there's a way to revive her. The ending felt really "blue-ballsed" if that makes sense.[/spoiler]
In all, I'd definitely recommend VII to anyone in my friend group, so they all can finally see the greatness that is the Neptunia series. The fan service, albeit seemingly cringy to the untrained eye, it takes a lot of it to desensitize one to the pretty images. 10/10 would nep again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093800261', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1560167249}
review:
Beat the main story 3 times already (Even tho my hours aren't registered I actually have over 300 hours). Still can't beat Neplunker (Zero Dimension). GG. EDIT: I finally got it after 1000 tries, it took lots of timing jumps and numb fingers ;n;

My advice for this game is: 

- Use a controller
- Don't play Neplunker unless you wanna rage and smash your computer
- For the first part of the game use skills instead of combos, I tried to play only using combos and I got killed over and over by regular monsters, lol
- Take advantage of combo traits, they work well against high level monsters, and if you use it correctly you can farm EXE Drive ;3

You'll figure out the rest.

Oh and did I forget to say that Neplunker is annoying?

So let's go with the Pros and Cons of this game.

Pros:

- Excellent Mechanics, New Characters, New NEP! Im not gonna spoil you, but this game is FIRE, probably  the best Neptunia game I've played so far!

- Amazing Story. I've played all Re;Birth games and they all had decent story, my favorite was probably Re;Birth 3 but hell... Victory II has a really interesting story that you should really try.

- Excellent Soundtrack. I still have some stuck in my head, they're really great, [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qfECDdNsEyk]this one[/url] is probably my favorite.

- Improved Scouting System. Hey, you can actually use stat effects from your scouts on the dungeons you enter!

- Fan seeeeerviiiiiiiice. This is what makes a really good Neptunia game.

- More variety in monsters and really open dungeons. Re;Birth games usually had small dungeons and pretty similar monsters. But this one actually makes you change your characters if you wanna deal significant damage, which is actually really fun and interesting!

Cons:

- There are few characters. Re;Birth games usually had over 20 characters that you could choose and level up, but this one has like 14 or less, some of them just feel the same, specially the new ones.

- Grinding feels pointless after you finish the game. Unless you get the strong equipment and weapons DLC it's gonna take you hundreds of hours to actually FINISH the game 100%. Base weapons and equipment are really weak compared to how strong monsters are in the high level Colosseum Battles.

- The story feels really short, it took me a lot of time to finish it the first time (I watched all the events and got all endings). If you skip the fan services dialogs and all of that the game feels pretty straight-forward. Maybe it's just me because I've played Neptunia for so long (Not that long actually, lol).

- Your weapon is really dependant on Combo Traits, and that's not all. Weapons are only distributed with a certain amount of combo strings. Like for example you can have a weapon that only allows you to use 4 Rush Attacks, One Power Attack and One Standard Attack. Which isn't really my favorite thing because yeah, you have the base damage for your weapon increased, but sometimes you need to use Normal Attacks, so depending on what combo strings your weapon has isn't my favorite thing about this game.

And that's pretty much it. Overall the game is really good! You should really play it! Get it on sale.

review:
Hat eine der besten Neptunia Storys und ist fÃ¼r mich leider dennoch Gamedesign technisch der schlechteste Neptunia Teil.
Ich wÃ¼rde das Spiel trozallem fÃ¼r die Story empfehlen.

Hier die GrÃ¼nde warum ich es fÃ¼r den Gamedesign technisch schlechtesten Neptunia Teil halte:

Warum muss ich dem Spiel 7 mal sagen das ich wissen mÃ¶chte wie die Story weiter geht (Event in der Stadt triggern), wenn dies in einem Event zusammen gefasst werden kann?

Das Road building System ist eine coole Idee solange mann nicht immer bis zum anderen Ende der Map laufen muss nur um die nÃ¤chste Route frei zu schalten, zurÃ¼ck zur Stadt zu gehen, diese Route zu bauen und wieder zum Ende der Map zu laufen.

Von dem verbuggten NG+/DLC Chars will ich erst gar nicht anfangen. (Es ist vom Entwickler gewollt das NG+ bei Char Import, DLC Chars / das True Ending verbuggt/unmÃ¶glich macht)

Das Schatten flackern fÃ¼r AMD, in Dungeons, konnte ich zum glÃ¼ck mit einer Anpassung in den Einstellungen vermeiden wobei dies auch mal gepatcht werden kÃ¶nnte.

Sonst ist Megadimension Neptunia Vii ein super spiel mit guter Story interesstanten Charakteren.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040343125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 6473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5373, 'last_played': 1605394739}
review:
TopNep, Peak Nep.

Pretty much improved on almost Everything in the Re;Birth games.

While i liked and enjoyed the Re;birth games very much, i wouldn't recommend them to anyone, but only to those who are heavily into animangaming and love Parodies and stuff (as they are basically a giant Parody of every thing nerd-ish). However i can recommend Megadimension to anyone who is into (J)RPGs.

Not to mention the Amazing OST. And finally, for the first time since R;B1, Makers are heavily integrated into the story, especially after their role was dumbed down in R;B2 and only became side events in R;B3. Nep & Friends are also at their best in this game.

My only real complaint about this game will be the difficulty, it was a bit too easy for my tastes, especially when compared to the Re;Birth games, who had a ''Fortify Enemies'' plan as difficulty toggle. Atleast Dangerous Monsters and some Boss fights are still pretty tough. Wish more were tough or even more tough tho.

TopNep

author: {'steamid': '76561198047876054', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2959, 'last_played': 1589725160}
review:
Best of the series. New great characters (cool girl Uzume) and magnificent soundtrack (01 Absolute <3). Longest and excellent storyline of the all Nep games. In one moment you smile, in another one you cry. Unfortunately, there is no characters from previous games (Plutia for example).
But hey, this is still Neptunia game, protagonist of protagonists as the "main" character, fourth wall breaker. Your daily dose of light humor, references to games and games companies (making fun of greedy developers and loot boxes). The battle system is still turn base like in most of jrpg but with some changes comparing to the other Nep games. The guard bar is no longer existing and now we can do combo chain with our attacks. About difficulty, in my opinion, the game is a little too easy. Sometimes we can hit a "difficulty spike".
 So, let Neptune grab her wooden katana and save Gamindustri once more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198170159766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1617609167}
review:
I've been disenchanted from this series for half a decade now because it all amalgamates to endless pointless dialogue and repetitive gameplay. However, this particular entry in the series is a step in the right direction. I do love the new and bigger dungeons and while I miss the break system for the combat, it's otherwise still as fun as I remember Rebirth 1 to be. The animations are still nice and the battle system, as easy as it is, still remains pretty engaging with how you gotta position characters and aim their unique aiming boxes based on the weapon or ability.

The same problems that plague the entire series are here: the tropiness, the eye roll inducing fan service, and worst of all, the bane of my existence; the slice of life fluff dialogue. Normally this would drive me mad and it still does to some degree (go and check all my reviews of other Neptunia games), but there's just something about Victory II that draws me to play it anyway. The improved graphics, the crisper looking cutscenes, maybe? In any case, I just learned to press the SKIP button during pointless dialogue then stop if I hear the music change to check and see if the boring dialogue becomes something that actually moves the plot forward.

Like seriously...who gives a damn about Nep getting pudding and all the ingredients needed to make it for her? Pressing the skip button I was surprised by just how much blocks of text that dumb interaction takes up. So while I still think this game series needs some work, this entry in particular is kind of redeeming the series as a whole, as I THINK the pointless dialogue is cut down to a degree. Just not a degree I prefer. A Neptunia script gives me the impression that the writers think that first drafts are amazing, when really they should be saying more with less text, ya know? Concision and precision is lost on these writers. I shouldn't have to skip so many lines of pointless dialogue to reach the meat of it.

So yeah I'll recommend the game as I AM enjoying it somehow. Just know that this entry, like the other ones, suffer from the same fate of having unedited first drafty feeling in the writing. The story isn't AMAZING by any stretch of the imagination, but it's decent enough to push the context of the dungeons and battles more. The story is good when it decided to move itself forward after all the fluff dialogue, but anyways at the risk of looking like a hypocrite by over writing myself, I will end my review and just say it's a good time if you're drunk.

Naaaaow it's uh PARty!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085941437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2073, 'last_played': 1553641202}
review:
[h1] Plenty of Annoyances - Get the Hyperdimension Games Instead [/h1]

I HATE giving a negative review for a Neptunia game. The cast of waifus is great, but the game is not as fun to play as the Hyperdimension series.

Are you new to the series? Play Hyperdimension Re;Birth 2 or 3 first.

[h1] Game-Breaking Bug [/h1]

You can read community-created guides that tell you you should NOT carry over characters for New Game Plus if you have DLC characters. You should ALSO not carry over your quest rank if you got your rank above E in the first play through. That is not something I have found on guides or other reviews, and it makes me wonder what else is involved in the New Game Plus bug.

You know, many of the "nice to have" features of New Game Plus are great. But if they couldn't fix the bug, they should have produced a free DLC or something that would remove the affected requirements for saving Uzume so that people aren't affected by the bug. I wonder how many other people have wasted 10 hours or more learning about aspects of that little bug. It would be nice to a have a full list of things to uncheck in New Game Plus as well.

[h1] Story - The "Sailor Moon" Volume of Cheese...But Flavorless [/h1]

The whole middle part of the game is the developers forcing a story to exist for the four "Sha" characters. It would be annoying without the fact that even on New Game Plus, your heroines arrive on the scene with only the clothes on their backs and the weapons in their hands (with the unique and odd exception of Neptune in New Game Plus). And this means that you then need to use the scouts, even on New Game Plus.

Honestly, given the quality of the middle part of the story, the developers would have been better off doing small events for the "Sha" characters like they do for the DLC characters. That would then free them up to write a story that will NOT cause the gamer to get a wooden spoon to bite on when they once again return to using scouts. A bit of writing quality would be nice as well.

[h1] The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]

+ Million Arthur (DLC)
+ God Eater (DLC)
+ New Characters (only playable for half of the game the first time around)
+ An urgent quest to kill "Pervert-san"
+ Popularity idea for Vert to get her own game: [spoiler] strip! [/spoiler] (works for me, honestly \o/ )
+ New Game + will allow you to play with the characters you want to play with from the very beginning (unless, of course, you want to save Uzume >.<). Also, you get to keep important things like weapons (unless, of course, this causes a bug I don't know about >.<).

[b] Annoyances NOT mitigated by New Game +: [/b]

- Neplunker (platforming dungeon) [spoiler] Thank Almighty Neptune for YouTube! [/spoiler]
- Scouts (unnecessary and annoying game mechanic that REALLY needs usability tweaks such as the possibility of marking and sorting scouts with a "favorite" system)
- Road building (unnecessary and annoying game mechanic that increases load time)
- Story system comes by way of "converse" option in towns...which makes it not seem like a game story. Also, this serves as a way to hide requirements to save Uzume from the gamer.
- Combo system: it is mostly pointless thanks to the required slots in weapons
- The item needed to upgrade your scouts is absurdly and pointlessly rare
- If quests will expire soon, that information should be passed on to the gamer.
- I think there is a bug in Player 2 Park with the rocket booster. I still can't get that treasure on the other side of the pipes.

[b] Serious Gripes: [/b]

1) You have one character die because you can't gauge the strength of an enemy in the middle of a dungeon where you can't save the game before the fight. You resurrect the character instantly and escape the battle with everyone alive. Your nation's shares take a 25 percent dip despite the fact you saved everyone. COME ON IFI! Seriously, why not give people a game over and boot them to the title screen the instant a CPU character dies? *IFI designers nod their heads and write down the idea for their next Neptunia game.*

2) If you invest bucket-loads of cash into a nation's economy to get plans for building stuff, you should be able to use those plans. Instead, you have hundreds of recipes, and you can build nothing. My scouts are out there hauling metric tons of goods back to my headquarters...and I can build nothing. Really? Building weapons takes mythical elements that you don't get from monster drops, hidden treasure, non-hidden treasure, quest rewards, etc. Hey, IFI, if this is a game aimed at teens, I honestly don't get this game design.

3) What is the purpose of giving the player quests for dungeons that will not appear until many hours of game-play later? Do yourself a favor and follow a guide for this game. I have never played a game where you can be doing everything you are supposed to do and still have no idea that you are actually doing everything you are supposed to do.

4) If I grind and grind and grind, I want to be able to purchase the next weapon for my favorite EX characters. Why can't I do that? Hours and hours and hours of game go by, and I can't upgrade the equipment for my favorite characters. What this means is that PAID DLC characters sit on the bench. The fish gets new weapons...why can't Nitroplus and Nepgya get new weapons? I have to believe this is just negligence on the part of the developers.

5) The most absurd boss battle I have in recent memory of a turn-based RPG:
[spoiler]
A) You are forced to put one character in your party that will contribute NOTHING to the boss battle.
B) Two of the four team members can only damage the boss with two of their regular attacks. Only one of them could damage the boss with magic.
C) Your super powered mega Nep attack does 0 damage over and over and over and over again.
D) If I hadn't bought the DLC weapons, would the fight have taken 4 hours? I don't know. I'm seriously glad I bought those weapons.
E) All this talk, all this hype, this miracle from the friends of the CPUs, A WHOLE NEW TRANSFORMATION FOR THE CPUs...and you do 0 damage on the boss. All I have to do to make fun of this is tell it like it is, folks!

IFI...really?
[/spoiler]

[h1] What Should Really Come Across with New Game Plus? [/h1]

[b] Implemented In Game [/b]

1) Weapons - they are a royal pain to acquire (the worst in the many IFI games I have played).
2) Cash - this is a requirement for returning the scouts to their day jobs.
3) The ability to skip the MANY over-world map battles with level 1 monsters.
4) The speedy shoes are VERY nice.
5) Character levels - this allows those that want to get all three endings the option of rushing through.

[b] Not Implemented In Game [/b]

1) Breaker Level - imagine my surprise when I couldn't break a metal box in NG+ despite having Breaker Level 2 on the screen.
2) Dungeons and all revealed secrets therein - the scouts can return to their day jobs in NG+, thank you very much.
3) EX characters - fix your bug, IFI (no, really >.<).
4) Quest Rank - fix your bug, IFI (no, really >.<).
5) Side events - they should be optional in NG+. Suffer through it once...then never again.


[h1] And the Swollen Middle Finger Award goes to IFI for this game because... [/h1]
[spoiler]
You MUST clear Neplunker Zero to get the good ending to the game.
[/spoiler]
Good grief.

I would have given the game a negative review without this thanks to the many other undesirable elements of the game. However, this one thing earns this game a very special place in my heart, and it shows what is wrong with the video game industry. Figure out who your audience is and make your game for that audience. This kind of steaming digestive waste does not belong in a turn-based RPG! 

[spoiler]
Having to raise my characters up 100 levels to beat a really nasty boss fight (Million Arthur) is within the realm of acceptable for a turn-based RPG. Neplunker Zero is NOT OKAY for a requirement to save Uzume! [/spoiler]

review:
TLDR: Get it ON SALE and ONLY if you like the Neptunia series. The combat and dialogue are nice but everything else is meh.

Bugs: Any dungeon that ends with "Forest" has a chance of crashing the game for no reason if you have a Intel HD graphics card. Most of the time, it'll crash after a fight.

"Fix": Run straight to the boss and save ASAP. In Vert's story, you have to do a required quest in Halo Forest. Fight 1-2 of those monsters then use the eject button. Do it over and over until you meet the quest requirements.

Dialogue:
- It's okay and made me laugh at times. Overall, it's a fun experience.
- English dialogue is missing a bunch of voice acting.
- Japanese dialogue has basically everything voice acted.

Story:
The story is separated into three parts: Zero Dimension, Hyper Dimension, and Heart Dimension.

Zero Dimension: Good hook with the mystery about Zero Dimension. Although, it's kinda completely forgotten about because we need to fight villains instead I guess. Umio and Uzume are cool.

Hyper Dimension: It's separated into four parts and YOU HAVE TO PLAY ALL OF THEM. And they're about the new characters instead of the CPUs. I mean, the interactions between them and the CPUs were okay and even fun at times, but it didn't add anything. The ending explains everything but it was unsatisfying for the amount of boredom I had to endure. At this point the game really overstayed its welcome in my head.

Heart Dimension: The new characters are playable. That's neat. (They are the best. Seriously, use them as soon as you get the chance.) The game then proceeds to throw you a "difficulty tweak" by having you fight 4 lvl 47 characters while the previous boss fight was one lvl 41 that you curb stomped. After that, the game demands you choose one of two routes, which will split your party into two groups. Not a huge fan of this.

I liked the ending but I'm not sure if that's just me being glad I finally finished.

Music:
- It's a banger I'll give it that.
- Sometimes the music will just completely drown out the voice acting. 

Gameplay in general:
- Technically, you don't have to grind at all. But having extra levels makes the boss fights even more of a curb stomp.
- There aren't too many dungeons in the beginning, but by the end, Hyper Dimension looks like a huge cluttered mess that I want to run away from. 
- The mini-bosses that scouts find are fun. 
- Bosses are sometimes the easiest thing in the dungeon and sometimes the feel like proper boss fights. The game has a habit of throwing in 2 boss fights in a row. So prepare for that.

Combat:
- The game is orientated around the combo system, which felt nice at first, but then became kinda boring.
- Variety is the spice of life, but you only get that spice when you change weapons or level up and hope that you get a new combo.
- Sometimes, the combos that a weapon allow you choose will not match nicely to the combo traits your character has.
- You will not get any more combos after level 60-ish, which makes leveling above that feel worthless and boring. Also IF is severely lacking in the number of combos.
- Regular skills are hardly used by me because of their SP costs. Most of the time, they aren't worth using. (Maybe except buff and debuff skills, but not a lot of characters have them anyways.)
- Formation skills are spammable. The whole "characters need to be in the same transformation state" thing is weird. Formations skills lack any real dps in the third chapter and using the EXE Drive to transform and use combos is the better option. They still look cool, though. Especially the new characters'.
- Thank God for the enemy change scout because the game becomes boring without a challenge. 

Challenges: 
- Your characters can become even better if you actually play with them!
- I don't know how good the effects are compared to a character you just got at the same level, so no real opinion here.

Plans:
- Maybe it's just me but I can't find any real reason to grind for the items for them.

World Map:
- I read somewhere on the internet that the routes were to represent the switch from copper wires to fiber optics. That's neat, but the animation time makes it even slower than just clicking on a dungeon and go, which is just ironic.
- Why are routes and random encounters a thing? I swear that each single node along a route has the random encounter chance rerolled because I have had 3 random encounters going on 3 nodes back to back before. Who thought that this was a good idea?
- I hope you like fighting underleveled mobs traveling from one place to the other.
- I guess it "makes sense" because the worlds are badly protected now but the random encounters are less "immersive" and more annoying. 
- At least have them scale to the average level of my front party or something. Make it less annoying by making it super rewarding. I would not be complaining as much if the exp was amazing from those mobs.
- The worst part is that my game has to load the world map all over again. What are you doing to my poor hard drive.
- Why is route building a thing? There's no reason for it. Why WOULDN'T I build the route in the first place? It costs like 1000 coins to build any route, which can be gained back by fighting a few monsters.

Scouts:
- They're there, I guess. Used to find secret stuff and items if you're into that.
- Time based, around 10 minutes for each scout. It's probably the reason why the game will stop if the window isn't in focus, which is the dumbest thing ever.
- It's super annoying to have to go back to the city just to tell them to go again. Especially if there are 10 nodes in between the dungeon and the city. 
- There's not a "Favorite" section or a "Choose All" button. You can send out multiple scouts at once, but you still have to manually go through all of them. 
- Scouts cannot report if they are in a different dimension than you are. Makes sense, but it is super annoying with the goddamn billion nodes in the way and did I mention random encounters?

Worth full price?
- No.

In conclusion, it's fun and made me laugh at times. But overall, you will start to see flaws that may ruin your experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060183002', 'num_games_owned': 732, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2750, 'last_played': 1549579096}
review:
Megadimension Neptunia VII isn't a bad game, but a severely flawed one. Lots of mostly small issues add up over the ~40-50h-campaign to craft an experience that, while not necessarily unpleasant, can't help but feel like a step back, especially when compared to Re;birth 3. The story, which is mostly being told through a seemingly endless mass of dialogue-sequences, in which a number of character portraits stare at the player while reciting the truly immense amounts of fully voiced dialogue, which ranges in quality from abysmal to actually quite entertaining, the latter mostly being the case whenever the game remembers it's supposed to be irreverent and throws out bizzare meta-humor or just good-old fanservice, is just confusing and weirdly paced. The game's marketing has made a big thing of the fact, that the entire middle section of the plot actually consists of four different story arcs, each focussing on one of the CPUs. The player is given free reign to play these in any order they choose. But every single one of them needs to be completed in order to advance the plot and nothing changes in any of them, regardless of the order in which they're completed, which just begs the question of why the developers let the player choose at all, if their decisions don't have any actual consequences in the game. In the end, the story-splitting is nothing but a huge gimmick, but one that robs the entire middle section of that all-important feeling of actually making progress, since you essentially have to start over with a new batch of low-level characters every few hours. This ties into a nasty habit, that has been clinging to this series since its inception: Everytime the plot demands that a character be gone for whatever reason, the game just takes them away. This wasn't that big of an issue in the previous titles, where the experience you gained during battle would be given to every character you had unlocked thus far, but in this installment, only the characters who fought gain any exp. whatsoever, which also removes any incentive to experiment with the lineup. A number of changes have been made to the rest of the combat system, as well: Enemies no longer have a guard meter or regenerate health every turn, the combo system has been entirely revamped, the CPUs have gained another transformation stage, even though you only get it so late into the game, that it probably won't see a lot of use and certain characters can be arranged into certain formations, at which point they'll be able to unleash a special formation attack. Overall the combat system has remained similar enough to its forebearers that fans of the series will get used to it quickly. The difficulty curve is a bit off, though. Regular enemies can at times be quite challenging, while most of the bosses are almost ridiculously easy. This has the added side effect that there's much less grind and by extension, less gameplay involved. But what little gameplay there is, serves its purpose and can even be pretty enjoyable at times. The overworld has also been reworked and unlike the battle system, almost all of the changes made here have been for the worse. Right out of the gate, the game commits one of the deadly sins of RPG game design: random, unavoidable battles on the overworld. I can not for the life of me figure out, how anyone on the development team could've though that this would be a good idea. Whenever you have to go from one city to the other, better be prepared to face a bunch of random monsters, who'll in most cases be so underleveled, that fighting them is neither challenging, nor in any way rewarding. Movement on the overworld is now confined to running along certain paths that the game lays out for you. Often though, you'll actually have to build these paths first, at the cost of credits. For the most part, though, there's never any reason not to build them, so one wonders why the game even gives you the option. Then there's the new investment system. Essentially, towns start off with only a small selection of things you can buy/develop and investing increasingly large sums of credits unlocks more possiblities. While this could technically work, it's hindered by the often trivial difficulty curve, which makes it safe to ignore most of the more advanced items and the fact that even basic materials are very hard to come by. The random goods scattered around the dungeons are gone, you see and now the only way to aquire things like, say, herbs, is through scouts, who can be deployed to a dungeon and have a chance at finding certain items, as well as hidden treasure and even entirely new dungeons. Even then, the game doesn't actually tell you , where to get certain items from, making item devolpment into a frustrating game of trial and error. Quite a substantial amount of content is only accessible through these scouts, but I pretty much completely ignored them, along with the item development, lily ranks, town investment, disc development, etc. and I got through the entire game without much difficulty, which begs the question of why they bothered to include any of this. 
Finally, the presentation: I normally don't really give a shit about graphics in videogames, but it has to be said, that this game, which was released in 2016 looks like it belongs on the PS3. The character portraits and overworld look fine, at times even pretty great, but once you actually enter one of the dungeons, you'll quickly notice just how empty and lifeless they are. The character and enemy models are betterr, but still not exactly brimming with detail. The game also valiantly continues the series' trend of reusing assets wherever they feel they can get away with it. Easily half of the enemies and dungeons have been taken from earlier titles and both are constantly being reused throughout the game. The sound design is quite decent, though. While I had the music muted throughout my entire playthrough, there seems to be a decent variety of it, also the insanely lenghty and numerous dialogues are entirely voice-acted, both in English and Japanese. 

In total, Megadimension Neptunia VII seems like a game with a lot of wasted potential. Some decent ideas buried under a metric ton of poorly thought out and/or poorly executed design decisions. If you're a fan of the franchise and have already played through Re;birth 1-3, get it on sale, otherwise I'd recommend to just play Re;birth 1.

review:

Me ha dado toneladas de diversiÃ³n sin tener que hacer pre- compra, que season pass, que tengo que comprar los DLC de forma obligatoria para disfrutar el juego. Nada de eso. Los DLC son opcionales. Como tiene que ser un verdadero DLC. Aunque admito que no pude resistir comprar a NitroPlus y al resto de los personajes DLC. Aun asÃ­ el juego sep uede disfrutar perfectamente sin los DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198317725973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4921, 'last_played': 1643416074}
review:
Just finished getting all the achievements in the game yesterday.. and I have to say it's a really great game.
The story was so deep and emotional at some points, it was so nice in my opinion.
However, it made me a bit sad to see that certain characters don't have that many sp skills (like Gold Third for example) since I also really loved them. Also the Next Form looks so cool! >~<

But yea another thing I'm gonna say is.. if you're planning on buying the game, I recommend you not to get the Ultimate Weapon DLC right at the start, as it makes you more op and it might ruin the fun for you if everything is too easy. But that's up to you after all.

If you're a huge lover of the series you should definitely get it.

review: The best Nep game in the main series. Visuals that look nicer than the Re;Birth series, awesome OST, great story and characters, and different yet familiar gameplay with new elements added in. If you enjoyed the previous games, you will surely love this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130424055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4526, 'last_played': 1492779870}
review:
Honestly surprised I had not left a review for this amazing game.

The soundtrack is incredibly fun to listen to, had more than a few times I would just leave the music running in the background due to how enjoyable I found most of it to be.

The storyline involves forced amnesia on masses of people and each nation having a new leader with a mysterious figure pulling at their strings in the background to keep the goddesses down. You later find out who it is, and how the story ends from there is all up to how you decide to play the game from there as there are three different possible endings that can be achieved,

The battle system has not changed much aside from some graphical updates to the UI. I did not find myself grinding too much until I reached a certain near end-game dungeon. I felt this game was slightly less grindy than previous games as I usually only spent about ten to twenty minutes grinding between levels. The only one I ended up spending longer to grind the levels for was Blanc due to her being solo for a good while before the new leader of Lowee and her younger sisters join her in battle.

The plot for this game ends up getting darker than Hyperdimension Neptunia 3: Victory did. More or less it is about [spoiler] a goddesses's inner darkness / original self (?) sepeating from herself and becoming an omnicidal maniac that tries to wipe out multiple dimensions for the fun of it. They come really close to achieving it too...[/spoiler] The story line is still really good since you see the goddesses having to cope with the idea for a short time of NOT being the ones ruling over their own nations while handling a threat from another dimension.

The 100% completing of achievements is probably the most grindy of all Neptunia games to date as it requires revisiting various places multiple times to complete mini-tasks set up for each one. Most of them are easy but some of them can be downright hard or nearly impossible to do unless you have a lot of patience.

Pretty fun game overall, would recommend at full price or on sale. The DLC is also worth buying as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133026460', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 303359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7015, 'last_played': 1654971869}
review:
[For Indonesian]
Finally selesai maenin semua neptunia games versi PC (Steam), kali ini gw akan review salah satu game neptunia yang akhir akhir ini gw maenin yaitu Megadimension Neptunia VII. Gw selesein ini game full storynya makan waktu 100 jam belum 100% achievement new game+, yap memang cukup lama. ok ga usah lama-lama gw mulai dari Storynya

[b] Story	[/b]
Untuk story pada game memiliki alur maju mundur, gw bisa di bilang ini game menarik dan bisa di bilang cukup membosankan.Gw bilang menarik karena, bertemakan apocalyptic dan future menceritakan tentang kehancuran yang sudah terjadi dan apa yang akan terjadi di masa depan, multiple endings, adanya pilihan (decisions),
penataan atau struktur antar tokoh dan npc bagus, memiliki story arc yang saling berhubung. Dan untuk bagian membosankannya yaitu ada beberapa jalan ceritanya mudah dibaca atau tahu ini nantinya bakal apa(predicted) dan feel JRPGnya kurang.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
Gameplay dan mekanismenya hampir sama dengan seri sebelumnya yaitu Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1,2,3 yaitu turn-based namun ada beberapa perkembangan seperti,
[list]
[*]Formation Skill
Formation Skill ini serangan gabungan antara 2 karakter atau lebih dengan ketentuan formasi yang ada. untuk melakukan skill ini membutuhkan EXE Drive, didapatkan melalui kombo pada fight but sometimes ngepas in formasinya susah,  terkadang ketentuan formasi terpenuhi tapi tidak bisa mengaktifkan formation skill.

[*]Map n Dungeon
Berbeda dari versi sebelumnya, untuk versi ini jika ingin menuju ke suatu dungeon atau kota harus melewati rute yang ada.Di selang perjalanan menuju ke kota atau dungeon akan ada random encounter which is ini yang gw benci.Untuk rute juga tidak sembarangan ada ketentuan membuatnya

[*]Scouts and Hidden Treasure
Scouts tak beda jauh dengan versi sebelumnya yaitu Stella Dungeon.Dimana kamu mengirim pengintai ke dungeon dengan waktu tertentu untuk mencari dan mempermudah dropable items dari monster, ketentuan hidden treasure, duit, dan memunculkan boss di dungeon.Scouts juga memberikan efek pada dungeon seperti Exp up, Credits up, Enemy Change, dll.Dan Hidden Treasure jauh lebih baik dari versi sebelumnya, untuk versi sebelumnya berbasis RNG untuk mencarinya namun untuk versi ini cukup mengirimkan scouts yang nantinya akan akan dikasih ketentuan untuk mencari hidden treasure tersebut seperti win some fights without healing, break some object,dll. 
Sidenote: Bug mempercepat waktu atau mengubah time zone seperti versi sebelumnya sudah tidak work, good job Compile Heart

[*]Next-Gen Transform
Ada transform tambahan dari HDD yaitu Next-Gen, transform ini merupakan upgrade dari HDD.Dimana akan ada tambahan skills dan tambahan stats yang membantumu saat battle.

[*]Big Bossfight battle
AH YES favorit part gw, disini melawan boss yang gede pake banget. Untuk mekanisme penyerangan hanya menggunakan skills saja, tidak bisa menggunakan attack biasa. Setiap turn akan diberikan MP jadi tidak khawatir akan kehabisan MP. Dan untuk pergerakannya tidak luas, dimana kamu berpijak ke puing puing yang sempit.Tentunya bisa berpindah ke puing satu ke lainnya dengan melompat untuk mencari formation skill.
[/list]

[b] Graphic (Visual) [/b]
Untuk game JRPG Rilisan tahun 2016 dengan spesifikasi tidak berat,  bisa dibilang bagus terutama di bagian efek blooms dan kualitas pencahayaan pada dungeon. Ya meskipun beberapa texture biasa aja tetap beautiful. Untuk Animasi dan Design pada skill dan cutscene juga ga kalah beautiful.And to be honest, sorry to say desain monster kinda boring karena monster barunya meh. Semakin ke level tinggi monsternya cuman beda warna.Karakter baru yang di hadirkan bagus dan imut tapi monster barunya mengecewakan.

[b] Sound [/b]
Seperti gw katakan di atas, kurang dapetin feel JRPG mulai dari suasana lagu di map, dungeon, dam bossfight.Well emang sih beberapa lagu pas dengan temanya apocalyptic dan future tetep masih ada yang kurang.Namun untuk dari segi opening lagu jelas bagus karena dinanyikan oleh [url=https://myanimelist.net/people/23365/nao] nao [/url] dan untuk lagu opening bisa cek[url=https://youtu.be/ANwyPAhAZ_Q] disini [/url].Hampir semua seri neptunia memiliki opening yang enak didengar.Untuk voice karakter menurut gw lebih cocok suara jepang ketimbang english, suara english terdengar aneh dan ga pas ama karakternya.

[b] Bug/Error [/b]
[olist]
[*]Serangan biasa lebih sakit daripada skills ataupun EXE Drive (?)
[*]Ketentuan untuk mencari hidden treasure terkadang tidak terpenuhi terutama di bagian symbol attack
[*]Untuk dungeon spelunker, melompat ke permukaan yang solid bisa jatuh sewaktu2
[*]Untuk Voice english suka error atau tidak ada suaranya
[*][spoiler]Untuk NG+, jika memasukan EX-member ke dalam party maka party akan dibubarkan waktu battle di story mode, ini sangat menganggu mengingat harus menyusun kembali party yang telah dibangun sebelumnya[/spoiler]
[/olist]
[b] DLC [/b]
DLC? ya gw akan review dlc pada game ini. Game ini tidak mempunyai difficulty macem easy medium dan hard ketika memulai game.Yep difficulty tersebut pindah ke dlc dimana kamu harus membayar untuk konten lebih. DLC-nya emang ga munculin difficulty ketika awal game tetapi dlc ini memberikan konten seperti   senjata, kostum, dan party tambahan. Dengan konten tambahan tersebut membuat game menjadi easy atau hard, jika tanpa dlc medium. Karena dlc pada game ini memberikan stats op dan nerf stats pada suatu kostum atau senjata. Bisa tentukan sendiri mau game easy menggunakan equipment op dlc, tanpa dlc medium, atau nerf stats dlc menjadi semakin susah.Lalu bagaimana dengan Party Character? Tambahan party karakter ini hanya sedikit membantumu ketika battle dan memberikan tambahan story. for me its 50:50 worth it

[b] Achievements [/b]
Untuk yang suka atau hobi ngincer achievement pada game ini yang murni tanpa cheat ataupun trainer, harap sabar jangan marah karena sebagian achievement bergantung pada RNG lagi xD

[b] Perbedaan Versi VIIR dan VII [/b]
Pada 23 Oktober 2018 Idea factory meluncurkan remake versi VII yaitu Megadimension Neptunia VIIR, berikut perbedaan diantara 2 game tersebut:
[olist]
[*]Untuk VIIR tidak ada hanya 1 save dikarenakan mempunyai sistem auto save sedangkan untuk VII mempunyai dan menyediakan fitur slot save
[*]Tentunya VIIR memiliki fitur VR dengan 4 karakter sedangkan VII tidak ada fitur VR
[*]Meskipun VIIR dikatakan remake, untuk graphic justru lebih bagus VII daripada VIIR hanya saja tampilan UI menang
[*]Versi VIIR hanya memiliki 1 ending, sedangkan VII memiliki multiple endings
[*]Versi VIIR tidak memiliki fitur New Game+ sedangkan VII ada
[*]Versi VIIR max 30 fps sedangkan VII max 60 fps
[/olist]
[b] Conclusion [/b]
Dari semua aspek yang gw jelaskan di atas tetap worth it â€œbuatâ€ kalangan wibu yang mencari  kesenangan(have fun) dan keimutan dari karakter pada game ini.All of these games are fun to play, masih nunggu seri nep games lainnya untuk pc.Untuk neptunia games non pc seperti (Ps3,PsVita,Nintendo Switch) belum kesempetan nyobain.

Review with picture bisa dicek ke [url=https://www.facebook.com/notes/henri-bakhtiar/megadimension-neptunia-vii-review/2360335540663428/] link berikut [/url]

[code] My final score for Megadimension Neptunia VII is 6/10 [/code]

author: {'steamid': '76561198071926221', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1544453169}
review:
I used to play JRPGs before in the original PS.  I was really excited to play this game.  

Sadly I can't recommend the game.  There is not much JRPG in it.  Mostly I remember playing this game is pressing the A button to continue a dialog.  Fights are boring, not much strategy in it.  Either you grind mindless fights to get credits to buy potions, so that you'll survive harder fights, that are equally boring.

..and dialog dialog dialog.  It is like a visual novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025102926', 'num_games_owned': 1729, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 12318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10738, 'last_played': 1644852507}
review:
This is a Neptunia game. If you know what I mean by that, go ahead and buy it. It's a good one.

If you're new to the series... the world is "Gamindustri", and that's no coincidence. Characters and locations are loosely based on consoles, gaming companies, or games. Everyone loves games, and the main characters in particular keep breaking the 4th wall. The games a lighthearted and fun, although you might consider them childish at times. Prepare for characters discussing their longing for pudding, or get into a stupid argument over something completely irrelevant while
the baddies are waiting for the battle to begin.

The game itself isn't a top-notch production. The story is told in a visual-novel style, and not all scenes have english voice
acting. Between the story segments is gameplay -- a JRPG where you go to dungeons. There are no interesting quests or anything -- dungeons are either about killing a certain number of a certain monster, or getting a certain item.  If it's a story-related dungeon then you'll just have to get from one event marker to the next, and (usually) you'll get a story-progressing bossfight at the end.

There's crafting, but it's basically a post-game thing which isn't particularly useful: during the plathrough you just don't have the resources, or the access to the resources.

As such, it might not be the most exciting gameplay ever. In my opinion, you play this for the story, but you'll have to be willing to stomach the seemingly endless sequence of visual novel segments. It's rated "T", as in "noT for everyone".

For a Neptunia game, production values aren't that bad. We get some new dungeons/environments/enemies, some great music tracks, memorable new characters, and even the visual novel segments have improved.

Things to hate about this installment include:
* Neplunker dungeons
* World map / random encounters (encounters get removed on NG+)
* Evonium / EnergyMate items
* Senmue labyrinth dungeons
* Max level is "impossible", which includes the colosseum fights at about level 200 and up
* Card master achievement
* Expectation boxes
* Plant Bracelet getting selected as "best item"
* Ugly hardgear, processor parts and swimsuits getting selected as "best item"
* Vert and the candidates being in the game (SCNR ... I know, it's personal opinion â˜º)

author: {'steamid': '76561198124128663', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 19795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12821, 'last_played': 1677906027}
review:
Megadimension Neptunia VII is honestly one of the best experiences i've had on steam to date. It's immersive story and gameplay mix extremely well together, and the replay value is increased with things like [spoiler] The Colloseum [/spoiler] and it's very open New Game+.
[h1] This is even great as a first entry to the series. It was mine. If you want the definitive Neptunia experience, start here, but not VIIR. [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198037038102', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4008, 'last_played': 1527355859}
review:
Neptunia series seem to never get old, even if little has changed over the years in gameplay perspective.
It's still roaming throughmaps and dungeons with familiar enemies and mechanics, combat system that is practically a natural reflexes at this point and bunch of likable characters that have grown on me.

Graphics  are familiar to those who have played other games of the series, just little more refined.
I wouldn't call them astounding but they certainly are not lackluster either.

Game mechanics are inventive and there's a lot to do, from quests to shareholding to building relationships,
Combat can feel repetitive for sure stronger monsters, formations and plenty of different skill patterns refreshes the experience.

Characters are the part where not only the game but whole Neptunia series shines. Old cast is as funny and likable as ever,
and new members don't feel out of place. Honestly, 

In summary I can recommend Neptunia VII to those who enjoyed earlier games of the series, and to those who aren't afraid of little dungeon grind-fest with anime(ish) graphics and nutty dialog. And to Anime game fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088167957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3336, 'last_played': 1587399907}
review: THE BEST Neptunia game I've ever played and I've played them all except Action Unleashed. Uzume is an amazing character. The Long expansive story was actually great for a Neptunia game. Gold Third was an amazing addition and I even wish they had their own game! My play time accounts for one playthrough! That's a lot of material! Everything about this game I give A++ I can't think of a single thing I didn't like! (Except Orange Heart's Dub voice... ugh) The jokes and tropes of your typical Nep game are still there and as funny as they come. There's so much more in this game than I expected. Loved every minute of it. Never felt too grindy but you still had to find some good EXP spots at times. The move varieties and changes to the EXE drive were welcome and there's so much more smaller facets to the game in the background that was really cool! I don't know if they can top this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413982927', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 3089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1923, 'last_played': 1694616800}
review:
I bought this game as an experiment to see how my friends would react, and let's just say it was a bigger plot twist than the game's storyline. They had never heard of the series, so they didn't know whether to be impressed or confused. I laughed my way through their reactions and kept playing, and to my surprise, the gameplay was actually pretty fun. I couldn't care less about the story or sidequests, but the gameplay hooked me in like a fish on a line.

Now, I'm no expert on anime or games like this, but I can confidently say that this game isn't half bad. It's got its own vibe, you know? If you're new to this category of games, don't get too caught up in the story. Trust me, it'll just make things boring and predictable. I should know, because this was my first game in the category and I still had a blast.

Sure, some of the landscapes were buggy and the graphics were a bit simplistic at times, but overall the gameplay was smooth and enjoyable. I'd definitely recommend this game to beginners or anyone who's played similar games before. Just don't expect your friends to understand what the heck you're playing.

review:
One of the best RPG's i've ever played!

I am quite fond of RPG's and when I found out about the Neptunia franchise, (which is filled with video game refrences and memes) I was hooked straight away. I've 100%'d HyperDimension Re;Birth 1, and i'm going to 100% this game too. A game has never gotten me as hooked as this game. Even with my PC's fairly poor specs, i'm having a blast streaming and showing my reactions to the story. Whatever you do, if you are a fan of video games, RPG's, cute anime girls or a combination of all 3, YOU MUST PLAY THIS GAME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038367822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 3770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3761, 'last_played': 1540099270}
review:
Recommended,
if you like the premise and have read up on the history of video games. Though even then I would recommend just watching the cutscenes on youtube. The actual gameplay does nothing worth your time.

What does Neptunia VII do right? The characters and the dialog. The casts personalities are entertaining, as are their dialogs with one another. Basically just the stuff in the cutscenes/dialog sequences

Is Neptunia worth your time?
If you're looking for a jrpg that's fun throughout the game, like Charles Barkley, Shut up and Jam: Gaiden, Chrono Trigger, Persona 5, EarthBound, or Skies of Arcadia, look elsewhere. The combat mechanics here are broken in the unfun sense of the word. The whole combo system used to attack lacks the spice needed to be interesting. A bunch of the moves you learn cannot be combo'd, making them borderline useless. The game isn't hard, but it isn't challenging either. Every boss fight that ever gave me trouble, I just went backwards and grinded 2-5 levels. And the grinding in this game isn't fun. Not one bit. Grinding sucks. 

If you're looking for a cool plot like Deus Ex or interesting character study like Planescape Torment, well... this is neither of those things. Frankly, as a fan of exploration based games, I wish I'd never played this.

Turn back ye who've made it this far. 
Go play something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068141034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 4845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4845, 'last_played': 1535307825}
review:
Wow, so many rave reviews. But after 80 hours of playing this, I have to say I'm a liiidle lukewarm where others have gone ape. 

Graphics: good. Kiiiinda. You don't get a 'wow' factor. The sprites and cutscenes are cartoony, and they're well done, but it's not like you can say the graphics are amazing. They nail what they were meant to nail, and if you like that style, then rah! Good graphics!

Porn factor: Not reeeeeeallly.. There's an early game trope of the girls bathing together, which fades fast they only do that a few times, and the subtitles cover most of their bodies. It's coy, suggestive titilation, nothing more. 

Dungeons and movement: In Final Fantasy, the first thing you know about a nearby enemy is the swirly screen, pachaaa! fight now! In Megadimensions you can see where the enemy are, and if you swipe them you get a tactical advantage (first turn, and/or less enemies than there would otherwise have been). But the swiping is kinda clunky, some of the enemies have massive hit boxes and you can walk into them before you've pressed the button, or swing wildly and hit nothing while the thing either walks away, or moves towards you and pachaaaa! lost the advantage! Enemy gets first go cuz it 'touched' you after your swing. It's an odd system, and doens't feel like it belongs in a top flight game, not at all. 

Later on, your scouts will find two hidden dungeons which are like platformy challenges. Frakking impossible! idk how anyone clears these dungeons, the in-dungeon movement is so clunky that these two dungeons are challenging for all the wrong reasons. 

Mega amounts of battle skills: well kiiiiiinda. There are a lot of combos, but the combo skills you learn become mostly redundant because of limiations built into the weapons you use. You'll use the best few skills that will fit on the weapon. :s and you'll only ever upgrade your weapons a few times (unless you get the weapon dlc, which reviewers have said makes the entire game a walk in the park). So... no... 

Mega amounts of battle skills 2: there are tons of coupling skills, and formation skills, and personal skills, and skills you can only use if you charge up the 'exe' gauge, and there are two transformed states.... well kiiiinda.... 

For most of the game, there isn't enough share energy in the story to transform and you don't have access to the transform states... also, when you dooo have access, it takes so many 'exe gauge' fills to transform your party, and then even more to build for using your transformed state skills.... you could have spent those exe gauges on regular battle skills, and won the fight by now! ..... its almost like you can only transform in a battle where the enemy is incapable of wiping you out no matter how long you spend messing about... and in such a battle... you were gonna win anyway, transformed or not ><

the coupling skills seem useless, and the formation skills (basically, you can surround an enemy, and a formation skill involves 2, 3 or all 4 of your party working together to do a huge amount of damage). Like with transforming, the formation skills are so expensive in terms of 'exe gauge' that you're better off using some of the lesser skills. Four people, using a 4-way formation skill, don't do 4 times the damage of 1 person using a regular skill. So it's pointless. Cool as hell! Awesome to see.... but.... unless you need to break equipment on the enemy (ver rare) then they're kinda pointless. 

Of the remaining skills, character and exe gauge skills, again, you're gonna use the best 1 or 2 on each fighter, so the dizzying array of skills you caaaan use, basically get pared down, logistically, to the same handful over and over. The mega amounts of skills are there.... they just don't.... register... 

Story: the girls are great, so much fun, so much personality! Kiiiiiiiiiiiinda.... there's a lot of metafiction ('hey, i'm the protagonist!' 'oh wow, here comes the boss battle!'  etc.) .. which, I think, metaficiton is always kinda hit 'n' miss... and there are two types of scenes in a story: plot points, and character development. Here you get a lot.... a LOT of character development.... I mean... little spats or funnies or stuff about pudding or bathing...etc. etc.. it goes on and onnnn and onnnnn omg, so much blah and blub, and very little of it is plot relevant. Much of it is character irrelevant too I think after a certain point. I think you have to love these girls' interactions to really get along with this game, and I found there was just tooooo much fluff, omg, let's just get to the next area/chapter/battle already....

tons of characters: yes, absolutely, crikey: 4 CPUs (leaders), 4 CPU candidates (like friends or sisters to the CPUs) 4 'x' I'll call them 'x' otherwise it'll spoiler the story some, and idk, 4, 5 or 6 helpers, sort of support characters in the story, but battle ready characters that you can use in fighting too, and they're comparable to the others, certainly viable options in battle. kk, yes, there are a dizzying array of characters you can use.... except you can't... 

In the first part of the story you can only use Neptune, Nepgear, and Uzume, and Uzume takes a back seat a lot of the time. In the second part of the story, you follow each of the CPUs in turn, and you can only use them and the candidates or helpers travelling with them... roughly two people in each fight as you follow 4 different story arcs, one after another.... In the third part of the story, you're restricted to using the CPU candidates for a loooooooong time, and then afterwards you're restricted to using the CPUs.... so it's like.... the story is encouraging you to engage with all these girls, but the game is forcing or denying you access to them for battles, and you end up levelling them all. 

Industry / Areas / Hidden Treasure / Development / Commerce: besides the main story and dungeons (hidden or otherwise) there is a HUGE amount you can do with the four nations here.... I can't really do it justice in the single para I want to devote to this, but you have scouts to send out, guild prizes to win, hidden treasure, area develoment (affects the things in the shop, and things you can make/craft), a gazillion outfits and accessories for the girls... these aspects of the game can be a bit dizzying, I mean, the potential for dungeon replay is huge when you factor everything together (hence my 80 hours, and I've only got 49% of the achievements!). To some extent this stuff gives you something to do while you make your characters stronger. To some extent this stuff feels like it belongs in a different game. To some extent, the story blocks off some of these aspects when you least need it to. Again, the game doens't feel slick and topline, more like mashed together with good ideas which arrive a little off key somehow. 

Battle: Occasionally you'll battle a boss in a 'sharing field'. These are immense bosses, and your party will be in a transformed state. These are visually stunning battles. 

Battle normal: Much has been made of Megadimension's battle system, people talk about it like its ahead of its time or something. I gotta say, its really what I expected from a turn based RPG. The battels are smooth, being able to use a controller is good, being able to move around without counting spaces is good, being able to hit more than one enemy if you place your weapon's arc in the right place is reeally good (tho beware, the bad guys can do that to you too!). It's just.... not stunning. Very good, it's a good battle system, that's where I would draw the line on praise for it. 

Overall: Megadimension Neptunia VII is moooore than the sum of its parts. Despite my lukewarm reaction to most of the game's aspects, I've played it every weekend for what seems like months now lol! The game is HUGE, epic in scale and story, it does grab you, it does engage, and it really delivers a memorable experience, if a little boggling and frustrating at times.

It smells like a combination of burnt popcorn, vomit, hot feces, a rotting dead animal, and burnt flesh. I should give it a fancy opera name like Fartma Opus in B Minor.

review: A surprisingly compelling JRPG that I need to play more of, but I just can't find the time. If it looks like something you want to play, I can safely recommend it to you. It is funny, heartwarming at times, and can even give you a bit of a challenge! It might not be the first game in this series, but it's not the worst place to jump in if you're a newcomer to the franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022971323', 'num_games_owned': 2600, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 3471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3471, 'last_played': 1536011833}
review:
Megadimension Neptunia is a very bizarre jRPG that combines a few styles at once in a fourth-wall-demolishing romp, making it a decent choice if you want something cute, funny, strange, and low-stress.

4TH WALL DESTROYED
The main character refers to herself as the protagonist, and various meta-style discussions take place throughout the game, which is filled with wacky humor and references to video game culture. (Various gaming companies are characters in the game. One plot point involves the villain vandalizing the protagonist's wikipedia page, and later the villain explains that people playing games don't want to hear about things like paying back loans.)

WEIRD OSCILLATING PRODUCTION VALUE
There's a lot of dialog sections with anime characters standing around, and some of the character art there like the man-faced-fish-man seems pretty low production value. But the dungeon-delving and combat takes place in a more traditional high-production value jRPG framework with moving around a battlefield to attack enemies in your weapon's radius via turn-based combat.

GRIND FOREVER IF YOU WANT
It's also obvious that this is one of those games one could play for 500 hours -- I finished the game with a lv49 party, and had climbed up to A rank on the hunter ladder, but was still slumming through the D-rank colluseum monsters... especially since the top mobs there call for level 900 characters. And I didn't find the hidden treasures in half the dungeons, nor did I develop 90% of the possible crafting recipes, and although I did manage to level up PR investment in all the towns, I hadn't boosted town commerce and industry to the max anywhere.

This is a weird game and if you're looking for something humorous and cutesy, I'd say go ahead and grab it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169156324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 13255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13134, 'last_played': 1535221062}
review:
Yeah, this is definitely a weird one for me. After I finished Metal Gear Rising: Revengance, this game suddenly appeared in my queue. I was instantly curious about this game because of the lack of gameplay featured in the promo video/pictures and the near unanimous amounts of positive reviews it had gained. I let it sit for nearly a year before I finally caved and bought it and three of the DLC characters. 

200 hours later...
I think it's safe to say I enjoyed this game and served as my gateway into JRPGs as a whole, but I'll get to those other games another day. For now, Neptunia is on trial. 

Setting: I had next to no expectations going into this game, but I was surprised with the setting and was my first introduction to the series's sense of humor. It's set on a continent called Gamindustri (oh don't worry, I'm just getting started) and each of the four nations represent one of the four major consoles currently on the market; Lastation represents Sony's Playstation, Leanbox stands in for Microsoft's Xbox, Lowee represent's Nintendo's Wii, and Planeptune represents Sega (obviously, they're out of the hardware game these days, but it's kinda fun to to think "What if they hadn't?") and each nation has leader called a CPU that represents the current console; Noire, Vert, Blanc and Neptune repectively. Even the younger sisters, called CPU Candidates, are references to handheld consoles, with Uni representing the PSP (or PS Vita. It's kinda unclear which), Rom and Ram represent the Nintendo DS and Nepgear represents the Sega Gamegear. There are also characters in these games called makers that represent game devs, but if I sit here listing every little reference I've found, we'd be here all day. Needless to say, the dev's attention to detail makes for great humor and is quite frankly impressive. 

Graphics: It's incredibly hard to judge the grapical quality of such a stylized game. It ultimately comes down to if you like the anime style or not, so it's dealer's choice when it comes to this. 

Story: This is what ultimately sold me on this game. The main story is broken up into three parts, each serving as their own contained story while tying into the others. The first one, Zero Dimension, starts with Neptune waking up after taking a nap in a park (as one does) and discovers a Sega Dreamcast. 

Seriously. 

Upon bringing it to her sister Nepgear, it opens up a portal and sends them to a different dimension where everything has been destroyed and they need to find a way back. This is the simplest of the three story arcs in this game, but it serves as a great introduction to the gameplay, characters, 4th wall-breaking humor and subtly sets up future story beats. It's also worth mentioning that Neptune does a great job of informing new players about characters and previous events that sometimes need clarifying (jarring to say the least, but in line with the established humor and helpful in general). Series veterans will say that you should start further back with the Rebirth games, but new players could feasibly start here and not be completely lost. 

The second arc, Hyper Dimension Neptunia G, picks up where the previous arc left off, with the four CPUs having been usurped by a group called Gold Third and discovering that the world no longer remembers them. This arc is further divided into four chapters featuring the four CPUs as the leads for their respective chapter. This particular part of the story surprised me with how dark it got at times. Or, I guess I should say attempted. To be honest, the overall tone of the game prevents to story from getting as dark as I was hoping. All four stories feature an unknown entity targeting the members of Gold Third in an attempt to break them mentally and physically, though it only really worked with B-Sha and K-Sha, in my opinion, with the entity targeting B-Sha's fear, almost forcing her to cause a masscre and K-Sha's lust, causing her to attempt to assassinate Uni in a misguided attempt to get Noire to fall in love with her. In any other game, this might've worked, but as I stated earlier, the game's overall tone prevents it from hitting as hard as it could've. Still, I appreciate the attempt. 

The final arc, Heart Dimension, serves to tie together the previous two arcs and finally reveal who has been pulling the strings in all three arcs. It was during this arc that I discovered that there were three different endings to the game, which is perfectly fine, but I was horrified when I learned that in order to get the true ending, you have to replay the entire the game in order to get there, as there are conversations you have to view AND several kill quests that are incredibly easy to miss if you aren't following a guide. Frustrating, but I wasn't as bothered as I should've been since the story was engaging, I was throughly enjoying the humor, the character interactions were enjoyable, and the game was fun to play. 

Speaking of gameplay: On the surface, this game appears to follow the usual JRPG-style of gameplay, but this is quickly disspelled when you enter battle. The "basic" attack in this game is a surprisingly deep and customizable Combo system, which enables you to string together a series of attacks in rapid succession. Certain attacks also have Combo requirements that give you a damage boost should you meet them and every weapon in the game has different slots in the three attacks (Rush, Power, and Standard), forcing you to get creative with your combos as you exchange your weapons. While not new to the Neptunia Franchise, this is certainly a big change in comparison to other JRPGs that I've played since finishing this game. 

Something else the CPUs can do is transform into their HDD state. This handled like any other transformation state in other games (strength boost and cosmetic change), but here it's tied to a depleteable meter that goes down as you use it or take damage. I don't like it, as it forces the player to limit it's use, which is a shame because the HDD forms serve as the serie's icons across all the games. It's also unreasonable to assume the player won't take damage in this JRPG.

Aside from the combat, everything else is rather standard. You explore dungeons in third-person, you traverse a large world map, and you grind for levels, which isn't as big of a problem in this games as others. You honestly don't really need to grind for levels as long as you don't go out of your way to avoid battling, unless you want to tackle Million Arthur's DLC quest where you battle level 100 lesbian clones of S-Sha, Uni, Vert, and Million Arthur. 

SERIOUSLY. 
That fight is no joke by the way, even if you ARE properly leveled. 

Sound and Voice: Sound effects in this game are handled well. Everything from the sword/spear clashes to the magic spells you can cast sound great across the board, even though they sometimes sound rather generic. What I really want to touch on is the voice acting. This game comes packaged with two dubs; the original Japanese and the localized English. I'm glad for the choice, as there will always be people who prefer one or the other, but if I'm being honest, the original Japanese is much better. This isn't an issue with quality as one might think. The dub is well done and there are even some characters I prefer in their English voices as opposed to the Japanese, but my preference ultimately comes to quantity. The Japanese dialog covers ALL of the story scenes whereas the English dub only covers what it considers "story crucial", though it's definition is dubious at best. Definitely recommend the Japanese dialog in this case. 

Conclusion: If I had to sum up this game in one word, it would be 'Fun'. Never at any point playing this did I lose the stupid grin that was stretched across my face. Everything about this game is fun, unique, and charming. I will certainly be keeping an eye on this franchise to see what comes next. 

Thanks for reading and have a great day :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2420, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1533791109}
review:
This is a massive game. It builds on the Hyperdimension trilogy in an epic way. New worlds, new combat... more jokes... The beginning has Nep and NepGear flung into a dying world, where they meet the last vestiges of resistance to a dark foe. From there, they have to make new friends (which is somewhat easy since it is those gregarious two) in order to stave off the destruction of that realm... and theirs.

I would say get the Deluxe or Complete Set, though it gets pricy. Maybe wait for a sale...

author: {'steamid': '76561198067743804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 6622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6535, 'last_played': 1568110403}
review:
Amazing and full of content. This is the highest point thus far for our CPUs and their friends.
It's got something for everyone and is the game that hooks new fans to the series.
It's such amazing value and compared to other games, not much comes close to the morality you get out of this game.
It's so easy to fall in love with these characters, the story get's cut up into easy to follow chapters and you get to see how each CPU uses their spotlight to tackle issues in their own incredibly personal way.

It just goes to show that even when you have everything taken away from you, 
You simply can't just give up, your accolades will be forgotten if you do.
The World will move on without you.
You have to Remember that you, are still YOU!, no matter how dire it becomes.
You can rebuild and achieve again! 
Don't let the actions of others Dictate your own Future, dammit! 
We are all capable of reaching the highs we once lost, we have to believe in ourselves. 
Your Future will always be in your hands, don't let anyone else nepping tell you otherwise!
